Judul: STUDY ON SIDE EFFECTS OF PSYCHIATRIC MEDICATION USED IN A MALAYSIAN HOSPITAL AND THEIR IN SILICO TOXICITY PROFILES
Abstrak:
Psychiatric disorders are still prevalent with the number of Disability-Adjusted Life Year (DALY) due to
psychiatric disorders increased from 80·8 million to 125·3 million and the proportion of DALYs
attributed to psychiatric disorders increased from 3·1% to 4·9% globally in this world. With a finding
a data from one of private hospitals in Malaysia, in 2019 around 29 types of psychiatric drugs were
prescribed and dispensed to patients. In addition, according to the National Anti-Drug Agency
Malaysia, the rate of abuse of psychiatric drugs is surprisingly increasing. With the rising use of
antipsychotic drugs in Malaysia, pharmacists and the physicians need to be aware of the adverse
effects. Severe side effects are hazardous to patients and might cause fatality. While the side effects
are sometimes unpredictable, the mechanisms can be studied using in silico approach. The aim of this
study was to compile psychiatric drugs most used in a Malaysian hospital, and further study their
potential toxicity using in silico methods. We collected data of patients under psychiatric medication
treatment. The psychiatric drugs used were classified into stimulant, antianxiety, mood stabilizer, and
opioid analgesic. The most prescribed medicine from each class was studied further for its toxic profile
using in silico method of OECD QSAR Toolbox v.4. In total, the number of patients under psychiatric
medication were 144 and the drugs were classified into stimulant, antianxiety, mood stabilizer, and
opioid analgesic. Representative drugs from each class were midazolam alprazolam, lorazepam, and
fentanyl, respectively. Results of the in silico study showed that alprazolam was associated with
hepatic and renal toxicity, midazolam with cardiotoxicity, lorazepam with hepatotoxicity, and
fentanyl with reproductive toxicity. Taken together, results of the present study warrant the
awareness of health professionals, especially pharmacist, for the potential toxic effects of psychiatric
drugs used in hospital setting.
